subtitle: [Music]
Thinking Allowed.
Conversations on the leading edge of
knowledge and discovery with
psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove. Hello and
welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Today we
are going to explore a chess game from
literally beyond the grave. With me is
Dr. Vernon Neppe, a neuropsychiatrist who
is head of the Pacific Neuropsychiatric
Institute in Seattle. He is the author of
numerous books including Cry the Beloved
Mind, Reality Begins with Consciousness,
and a trilogy of books about deja vu.
Welcome, Vernon. Thank you so much, Jeff.
It's a pleasure to be with you. In
introducing you I should say something
about your credentials as a chess player
at the master level, a chess champion
from South Africa, a person who organized
the first interracial chess tournament
there. South Africa. In fact, the first
interracial athletic event if one
considers a chess tournament to be an
athletic event. Yeah. Chess Match, which
was organized between the Witwatersrand
University Chess Club—I was captain
of the Witwatersrand University chess
team. We were approached by a group
of players who did not have a name for
their club from Soweto. They were
ultimately called the Soweto Chess Club
and this became the first multiracial
sports game, if chess is regarded as a
sport in South Africa. We discovered
at that stage—it was around about 1970—
that it was legal provided we did not
serve alcohol. As a chess
player you're one of the rare individuals who could play, I think
you told me, as many as 80 people at one
time. That is true. I had some challenges
in terms of playing chess
exhibitions and it's rather exciting because
people think, “Oh well, you've just got to
look at each board.” But of course there's
a planning component. Planning in
chess is the key component.
Beyond playing multiple people at one
time and looking at the chessboard you could
even play blindfolded. Yes. I used to play
blindfolded chess but I have to admit I
would choose my opponents very carefully
because the quality of my chess would
diminish down markedly. But in any case,
you're a scholar and an individual who
has an understanding of what it means to
play chess at the Master or Grandmaster
level. Yes. I try to understand that and
try to understand a piece of the history
because what we’re going to discuss relates
to events pertaining to a player in the
early part of the 20th century.
Géza Maróczy was the number two
player in the world round about 1905. So this is
highly pertinent in relation to his
ostensible, let us say, the ostensible
Géza Maróczy playing Viktor
Korchnoi. Korchnoi was, strangely
enough, the number two chess player in
the world round about 1980, and in fact
later on became the world senior chess
champion. We're talking about a game that
took place between 1987 and 1993,
initiated by a Swiss scholar and
researcher who had the idea that
evidence for survival after death could
be enhanced if it were possible to
obtain the agreement of a deceased
spirit who would be willing to
manifest through a spiritual medium and
play chess with a living Grandmaster.
This is a remarkable story. Since
Maróczy’s death in the very early 1950s,
suddenly a communication ostensibly
partly arising from the alleged—and I'll
use that word “alleged” repetitively and
if I don't please understand they are
meaning alleged, I'm not trying to say
this is definite or this is not definite—
but from an alleged communicator beyond
the grave who was a champion chess
player. Dr. Wolfgang Eisenbeiss, whose
doctorate is in economics in Switzerland,
came up with the idea that maybe, just
maybe, this would be the way to be able
to prove survival after bodily death.
Eisenbeiss himself was an amateur chess
player. Yeah. I've gone through Eisenbeiss’s
games, one or two of them, and
his level is that of a good, probably
grade B player. He's not bad.
The reason why I went through
one of his games is possibly the start
of the story. It's not published but
it's very interesting because I often
get people saying, “Well, you know, this is
obviously fraud between the medium
Rollans.” Or, I've had Eisenbeiss being
accused of fraud. Ultimately when one
starts looking at the data it will
require a major conspiracy because there
was even a Hungarian librarian involved.
Eisenbeiss did not talk any Hungarian
and a little bit of Maróczy’s family
were rather ambivalent about all of this
and were also involved. But in any event,
Eisenbeiss, when he started and first
interacted with Robert Rollans, the
medium… Who would do the automatic writing.
Initially. What happened was he came
up with something rather interesting. He
discovered that
Rollans could not play any chess. He
had to at least teach him a little bit
about the notation of chess so he could
record this during automatic writing.
Eisenbeiss said to him, “Well, you know, like
can you prove this is real?” Robert
Rollans's father, late father, the medium’s
late father, was an avid chess player.
Eisenbeiss, over a period of that day,
played him a chess game and that is also
recorded. A very poor chess game
with some interesting components of
knights ending up in the corners of the
board. I played through it. One of my
Master friends played through it. A
Grandmaster played through it. We all are
of agreement that this was very much an
amateur game. But in terms of standards
you could see he was a B-level player.
The reason of course is, this allows
him probably to have been able to
interact and do the chess stuff and know
something about it, but he certainly
wasn't at any kind of level where he
could have produced any of this. Because
what we're talking about here in terms
of evidence for survival has to do with
a skill, the skill of playing chess at
the Master or Grandmaster level. That
is not a skill that can be replicated by
somebody, I presume, who hasn't studied
chess extensively. That is true.
Even if they had studied chess
extensively it would be very difficult
for them to replicate that kind of level.
So this case at times has been called
the number one case in terms of proof of
survival after bodily death. There
are several different sources that one
could argue supporting that contention
or the way they've described it. But the
reason is it's not only the skills that
are involved, it is a combination
of skills and data. There's an
enormous amount of data that was
generated. Let's talk about that data
because as I understand it Maróczy,
through automatic writing, was asked a
number of questions, detailed questions
about his life when he was alive as a
chess player, obscure questions about
various matches and things concerning
his personal life. He was able to
answer these questions through automatic
writing with an incredible degree of
accuracy. Exactly that. They divided
up these questions into general
questions, the kinds of questions that
one could find when looking it up in
libraries or from the records of chess
tournaments, and very, very esoteric
questions that only Maróczy would
know and that could be validated.
This is where this Hungarian librarian
came in, who was not told this was a case
of potential survival, he was just told
that some kind of biography was being
done on Géza Maróczy and he went
searching. Some of these esoteric
questions required his family but also
there were answers to questions that
appeared wrong and later on were shown to
be right. For example, the famous one
is the Romih, R-O-M-I-H, sometimes
spelt slightly differently.
Maróczy said, “No, I didn't play that
person,” and they said, well he
did. It turned out that afterwards he pointed out that it was spelt
differently. Another one related to
Vera Menchick who was a famous women's
chess player at the time, a question of
who was linked up with a particular
chess club. People didn't know the answer
until afterwards. So we're talking about
not only esoterica but esoterica
that at times were not even known.
When one looked at the incredible degree of
accuracy it's very interesting because
Eisenbeiss and his co-author Dieter Hassler
initially published the data and they
pointed out a couple of errors that
Maróczy had made. When one started
looking at it the questions were not
necessarily erroneous. For example,
Maróczy had spoken about the fact
that he played somebody twice in a
particular tournament and effectively he
scored one point out of two. Now, you can
get that from two draws or from one win
and one loss. Ultimately it was
correct but it was perceived as wrong,
but it was wrong in the context of win-
loss instead of draws or vice versa. This
kind of subtlety. Another time, who came
third in the tournament? Well, you know,
you play chess tournaments, you might
have won it but seldom would you know
who came third. He had said one
world-champion had come third when
another of the world champions had come
third, this kind of thing. So there
were really, really subtle areas of error
even in sort of the general historical
data. When it came to the esoterica
there seemed to be absolutely nothing wrong
with his answers even though no one
living alive at the time could have
given all those answers. They were
specially composed. Eisenbeiss composed
them and this was well, well researched.
I can imagine a critic would say
that's proof it was fraud because you
never get close to a hundred percent
accuracy in survival research or
parapsychology research. Of course
one could argue this both ways. When
one looks at psi research amongst the living
and one looks at tests in labs you're
getting nowhere near a hundred percent accuracy.
You might statistically get accuracy and
score over a thousand hits and be at the
52 percent level when you expect it to
be statistically at the 50 percent level.
The data in survival research is much, much
higher in regard to this. Of course,
somebody like Gary Schwartz has also
found the same kind of figure. But the
important thing is about the accuracy
that some of these things appeared wrong
and we knew them as wrong. If they were fraudulent
one would have stayed with the wrong
bits of information because it was
thought to be right, and later on has
been found that Maróczy’s answers were
correct and these were incorrect. So the
important point here, and this to me is
the key to this whole case, there are two
keys. The one is data and skills, amazing
when you put them together. The second is
the interesting one of extended survival.
You see, it's not a case of: well they
played this game quickly over a period
of a few minutes and maybe Korchonoi was
fabricating this all or maybe some
other master was involved and quickly
consulting with Rollans and the moves
were delivered to Eisenbeiss and they
were delivered by automatic writing so
there is a record of these and I want to
write a play on this. Wolfgang
Eisenbeiss has been kind enough to send
me all the transcripts he has available.
I've been able to see these in a
written format as well. So the idea of
survival here is not just a fragment
moment of survival, maybe this was a
memory or something caught in space. This
was over a period of maybe six
years and was over a period of time when
strangely enough a prediction was made
that Rollans would be able to complete
this and he did, and then he died, which
was just another esoteric piece of
information. Of course, his wife has
been interviewed as well. This was
the most honest of individuals
apparently. He did a lot of mediumship,
never accepted a penny for this, had no
real, let us say, financial motivation to
do this. Nor did Eisenbeiss.
Eisenbeiss kept this very, very quiet for
some years. It wasn't until
2006 I believe, or 2007, that he published
his analysis of all of the information
that the ostensible spirit of Maróczy had
provided. He was encouraged to
do this but it was years later. He had no
intention of really achieving great
publicity out of it. But strangely enough
there were some important components that
came about because in the middle of the
game the press somehow got hold of it
and they ran a story. It could be
argued, if this was fraud they were
also keeping a great eye on this all the
way through the second half. There
was a Swiss chess champion at
the time who also very early on had gone
through this. Korchonoi had later on
commented, even before the end of the game,
how well Maróczy was playing. He wasn't
even sure if he was going to win the
game. So there were these different
elements. But later on there was another
person who ostensibly examined it beyond
me, at a far far higher level of chess.
We're talking now about the American
chess Grandmaster Bobby Fischer who is
the brother-in-law,
it turns out, of parapsychologist Russell
Targ. Yes, and it was
apparently through Russell that this all came
about. Russell, probably at Bobby
Fischer's request… And of course Bobby
Fischer some would argue is the greatest
World Chess Champion in the history of chess. He might have been the greatest
player in the history of chess but of
course became extremely psychotic as
is well known. There have been movies
made about it. But possibly as a
consequence of Russell I understand that
Bobby Fischer also went through this
game… Move by move. I haven't got the
details he went through because when you're playing at that level of
chess you can virtually eyeball
the whole chess game and know what is going on.
His comment was anyone who could
give that kind of level of fight to
Bobby Fischer over that number of moves…
You mean Korchnoi… To Korchnoi, yes…
Was somebody who's probably playing at
Grandmaster level. This was not my
evaluation. But you also did your own
evaluation move by move of the match.
Yes, but the most important component was,
I read this report and I thought this is
very interesting. I published this in
the Journal of the Society of Psychical
Research, making comments about my
strengths and weaknesses historically as
a chess player. You don't consider
yourself a Grandmaster? No, and I gave up
chess many, many years ago. However, I said
to myself, this is something that needs
to be sought after. We had a control
and that was computers. Now, computers in
the late 1970s, early 1980s, are not like
the chess computers today. Chess computers
today… I'm afraid this is one of the last
bastions of humanity beating up robots
and artificial intelligence and it's failed.
It failed because chess computers now
can beat even world champions. But in
those days that was not so.
I took a chess computer program that
I had, and I would actually regularly
play this program which
probably plays at the low master level.
I won maybe 98% of cases. So
this is the kind of level it's playing.
It's certainly very beatable but
this was the level of chess computers of
the day. The question came up, maybe,
just maybe all this is fraud. The chess
computers could possibly have faked this
all or somebody could have faked it
through the chess computers. What we
found was that first of all the style of
Maróczy—when you're at that level
in a world championship level, even in
1905, you have particular kinds of styles…
Based on the cultural historical era.
Also based on the individual player.
Every player plays differently. You can
recognize the games almost of a Bobby
Fischer, somewhat. You can
recognize the games of an Alexander Alekhine.
You can recognize the games of Akiba
Rubinstein. You can recognize the games
of Nimzowitsch. In the same way you could
recognise the games of Maróczy.
So, this stylistically was so. I
set this computer such that what would
he respond or what would she respond or
it respond, give it a personality. Maybe
in today's PC world we'll say “she.”
But what would the computer respond?
We were able to see that this was pretty
much impossible for the computer to have
replicated this game. I played the
game as well and could see it in the same kind
of fabric. We were dealing almost with
somebody who was expressing a
personality structure.
When you play chess weekly you're not
expressing that structure. When you plays
chess at that kind of level you are.
There's a style that you have and this
was the style of Maróczy just like
there was a style of Fischer. In
addition to skill and information you're
saying the personality of Maróczy came
through in this example. it came through
also in some of these questions, the Romih
question, the Vera Menchick question.
I used the example of Fischer.
There is a funny story which might
illustrate the link up a little more. I
had the good fortune to lecture in South
Africa on the Fischer-Spassky chess
series. In one of the games one
of my listeners who would listen avidly—
the move would come through the radio at the time
and I would say, Fischer's next move will be
X, and sure enough Fischer's next move
would be X—somebody came up to me
excitedly and said, it
was 37 moves or something of the sort
in the game and he said, “You’ve got the same
move as Bobby Fischer 35 of the 37
times.” I said, “That's why I'm not
Bobby Fischer,” because chess is an
absolute unit. When one looked at
this Maróczy game he was losing it by
playing an inferior move very early on
in the opening. This wasn't really
his fault because that was the move that
would have been played in 1905. When he came
back and was playing more chess in the
1930s for example the alternative
refutation was unknown when he passed, as
far as I remember it was in 1951. So,
his move was what was known then and it
was a good move but it was not the
appropriate move for the 1970s. The
ostensible spirit of Maróczy said he was
rusty. This is a game in the 1980s… He
made the comment that he was rusty…
He hadn't kept up his chess skills. When
we did an analysis we said, okay maybe he
was playing at the high master level, some
would say the Grandmaster level.
Fischer said this was like a Grand-
master. I think it was of the high master
level or even at the low master level.
You've got to understand that chess
theory has so developed that in order to
keep up with chess you have to keep up
with the theory and it takes a long, long
time. People are full-time
professional chess players. They spend
six-eight hours a day training in their
chess, studying chess theories.
When you prepare for
a World Championship like Magnus Carlsen,
the current World Chess Champion, he was
lifting weights, he was playing a lot of
table tennis, he was getting as fit as
anything because it is so stressful and
so difficult in terms of physical
components. So there's the physical
aspect that would go on and there is the
absolute preparation such that I, lonely
I, at this stage or when I was playing
chess regularly and was keeping up with it,
it is possible that I could have beaten
the Maróczy of 1905, not because he
wasn't much much better than me but
because chess theory is such that he might
have failed because of ideas that
changed. Once you have a minimal
advantage in chess, if you're a really
good chess player you can carry through
that minimal advantage and you win as a
consequence of it even if you're playing
against a world chess champion sometimes. They might be able
to get a draw but they might not be able to.
But of course they don't give up those
minimal advantages, they are too good for
that. Of course in this particular
match Korchnoi did win. Yes, Korchnoi
did win. This put paid to the idea
that well, if this was going to
be fabricated, wouldn't it have been nice
if Maróczy won. You know, it's
fascinating when you start looking at
how the media talks about it. In fact, in
one of the Bobby Fischer movies they
talked about people who were mad in
chess and they pointed to Fischer
and they pointed to Steinitz.
Steinitz, as far as I remember,
way back in the 19th century announced
that he wanted to play God because he
said he would beat God in chess. So you go
backwards in time and who was quoted,
poor Korchnoi, but they didn't say he played
it. They said there was this chess champion
Grandmaster, one of the leading players
in the world, who claimed he played
a ghost and this is ridiculous. They
made a joke about it. When you start
looking at it, extended survival over a
period of time is quite something and
because of it you've got to look at all
the alternative explanations.
Vernon Neppe, our time is up but this
has been a fascinating discussion of
what is probably, while not a hundred
percent conclusive, one of the strongest
cases we have for evidence of survival
after death. Thank you so much for being
with me. Thank you, Jeffrey, it's my
pleasure. Thank you. And thank you for
being with us.
[Music]
